moves.1. e4:
Hi everyone!

I finally decided to join the Traxler Mini-tournament and managed to finish my first game in it with a win today.  It was amazing just how it seemed to all come out of nowhere!
moves.1... e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Nf6: 3. ...... Nf6 - this move characterises the Two Knights Defense.  My next move which is Ng5 hits out at the weak f7 square and threatens a nasty Q + R fork on it.  The move d5 is normally played but here a counter-attack is spawned by the developing move Bc5 hitting out at f2.
moves.4. Ng5 Bc5: 4. ..... Bc5 - this is the move that gives the opening it's name.  It was called the Wilkes-Barre Variation but is now known as the Traxler.
moves.5. Bxf7+: 5. Bxf7+ - played by Kasparov, if it's good enough for him then it should be good enough for me!
moves.5... Ke7 6. Bd5: 7. Bd5 - this move is recommended by Wikipedia and is the most popular move in the World DB.
moves.6... Rf8 7. O-O: 7. 0-0 with a semi-open f file it makes sense to oppose rooks on it.  The WR adds a defender to the f2 pawn which is under the hammer of Alex's dsb.
moves.7... Ng4: 7. ...... Ng4 - what's this?  His knight is en prise.  Can I safely nab it?  On analysis I decided it was safe to do so.  In fact my opponent anticipated this capture because he put in the sneaky move d6 as a conditional!  No doubt he was hoping I would not notice Glenda was en prise!
moves.8. Qxg4 d6 9. Qg3: 9. Qg3 - but unfortunately for my opponent Glenda is alert and moves to g3.  Because my g5 knight is in the way, Glenda is a little camouflaged in her intentions, she is eyeing up that g7 square.
moves.9... h6 10. Nh7: 10. Nh7 - now Alex must drop the exchange (already a piece down) to avoid copping Old Matey.
moves.10... Rh8: 10. ...... Rh8.   He saves his rook but ......
moves.11. Qxg7+ Ke8 12. Qf7#: 12. Qf7 MATE!! - ...... loses his king.  I am now playing Alex with the black pieces.  I need to be wary.  After finding myself in the Dentist's Chair a few times (The Dentist is a buddy of mine whose rating fluctuates between 1250 and 1350) I cannot afford to be complacent.

opening: two knights defence (C57), Wilkes Barre (Traxler) variation
